threats.title: Spoofing the DDF Catalog Framework Process
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Metacard App. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Metacard App. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.

threats.title: Spoofing the Metacard App Process
threats.description: Metacard App may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by DDF Catalog Framework. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by DDF Catalog Framework. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for Metacard App
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against Metacard App or an elevation of privilege attack against Metacard App or an information disclosure by Metacard App. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against Metacard App or an elevation of privilege attack against Metacard App or an information disclosure by Metacard App. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by Metacard App
threats.description: Metacard App claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Metacard App
threats.description: Metacard App crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App is a trusted process/entity and is in the same system as the Catalog Framework.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: Metacard App may be able to impersonate the context of DDF Catalog Framework in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App runs on the same system as the Configuration Endpoint.

threats.title: Metacard App May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be able to remotely execute code for Metacard App.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework may be able to remotely execute code for Metacard App.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Metacard App
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into Metacard App in order to change the flow of program execution within Metacard App to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: The Catalog Framework is a trusted entity.

threats.title: Metacard App May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: Catalog Search UI Client may be able to remotely execute code for Metacard App.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including Metacard App's endpoints.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into DDF Catalog Framework in order to change the flow of program execution within DDF Catalog Framework to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including DDF Catalog Search UI's endpoints.

threats.title: DDF Catalog Framework May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: Metacard App may be able to remotely execute code for DDF Catalog Framework.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App is on the same system as the Catalog Framework and is a trusted process/entity.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be able to impersonate the context of Metacard App in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App runs on the same system as the Configuration Endpoint.

threats.title: Data Flow Request Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Metacard App is a trusted process/entity and is in the same system as the Catalog Framework.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All Requests and Responses passing through the Catalog Framework are audited, errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against DDF Catalog Framework or an elevation of privilege attack against DDF Catalog Framework or an information disclosure by DDF Catalog Framework. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including DDF Catalog Search UI's endpoints.

threats.title: Spoofing the DDF Catalog Framework Process
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by Metacard App. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Spoofing the Metacard App Process
threats.description: Metacard App may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to DDF Catalog Framework. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.
threats.mitigation: Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Spoofing the DDF Catalog Framework Process
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to User App. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data before it is sent. Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Spoofing the User App Process
threats.description: User App may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by DDF Catalog Framework. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data before it is sent. Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for User App
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against User App or an elevation of privilege attack against User App or an information disclosure by User App. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: Data should be encrypted before it is sent. DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including DDF Catalog Search UI's endpoints.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for User App
threats.description: User App crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: If the User App crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: User App is a trusted process/entity and is in the same system as the Catalog Framework.

threats.description: User App may be able to impersonate the context of DDF Catalog Framework in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Catalog Framework runs on the same system as the User App.

threats.description: Configuration Endpoint claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Configuration Endpoint is a trusted process/entity and errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Configuration Endpoint
threats.description: Configuration Endpoint crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: If the Configuration Endpoint crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Data Flow Query Request Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities. If the Configuration Endpoint crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: Configuration Endpoint may be able to impersonate the context of Catalog Search UI Client in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Configuration Endpoint is a trusted process/entity and will not attack the client(s). Authentication options are available for verification of legitimacy/identity.

threats.title: Configuration Endpoint May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: Catalog Search UI Client may be able to remotely execute code for Configuration Endpoint.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including Configuration endpoints.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Configuration Endpoint
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into Configuration Endpoint in order to change the flow of program execution within Configuration Endpoint to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including Configuration endpoints.

threats.title: Spoofing of the Catalog Search UI Client External Destination Entity
threats.description: Catalog Search UI Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Catalog Search UI Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data before it is sent. Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: External Entity Catalog Search UI Client Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: Catalog Search UI Client claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: If the User App crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Spoofing the User App Process
threats.description: User App may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by Catalog Search UI Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Spoofing the Catalog Search UI Client External Entity
threats.description: Catalog Search UI Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to User App. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for User App
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against User App or an elevation of privilege attack against User App or an information disclosure by User App. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including DDF Catalog Search UI's endpoints.

threats.description: Query CQL Endpoint may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to DDF Catalog Framework. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.

threats.title: Spoofing the DDF Catalog Framework Process
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by Query CQL Endpoint. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: Various authentication options are available over HTTPS. Default authentication is present as well.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against DDF Catalog Framework or an elevation of privilege attack against DDF Catalog Framework or an information disclosure by DDF Catalog Framework. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All Requests and Responses passing through the Catalog Framework are audited, errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: If the Catalog Framework crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Data Flow Request Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: The Query Endpoint is a trusted process/entity and is in the same system as the Catalog Framework.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: DDF Catalog Framework may be able to impersonate the context of Query CQL Endpoint in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Query CQL Endpoint runs on the same system as the Configuration Endpoint.

threats.title: DDF Catalog Framework May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: Query CQL Endpoint may be able to remotely execute code for DDF Catalog Framework.
threats.mitigation: Query Endpoint is on the same system as the Catalog Framework and is a trusted process/entity.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in DDF Catalog Framework
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into DDF Catalog Framework in order to change the flow of program execution within DDF Catalog Framework to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including DDF Catalog Search UI's endpoints.
